sen.j: 「南無」はnamo (サンスクリット語) の漢語への音写語で「わたくしは帰依します」と意味し、「妙法蓮華経」の五字はサンスクリット語の「サッダルマ・プンダリーカ・スートラ(saddharmapuNDariika-suutra、)」を鳩摩羅什（くまらじゅう、サンスクリット語 Kumārajīva,、クマーラジーヴァ、略称 羅什（らじゅう）または什（じゅう））が翻訳した版の法華経の正式な題名（題目）である。
sen.e: "Nam" is a transliteration of the original Sanskrit and means "I devote myself". The five characters 妙法蓮華経 "myoho-renge-kyo" are Sanskrit for "saddharmapuNDariika-sutra" सद्धर्मपुण्डरीक सूत्र the formal title of the Lotus Sutra which Kumarajiva (abbreviated as Raju or Juu) translated.

"Nam" is a transliteration of the original Sanskrit and means "I devote myself." The five characters 妙法蓮華経 "myoho-renge-kyo" are Sanskrit for "saddharmapuNDariika-sutra" सद्धर्मपुण्डरीक सूत्र the formal title of the Lotus Sutra which Kumarajiva (abbreviated as Raju or Juu) translated.

"南無" (Namu) is a transliteration of Namo (Sanskrit) to Chinese and it means "I devote myself,"and the five letters, "妙法蓮華経"(myoho-renge-kyo), were the formal title of Hokkekyo (the Lotus Sutra) when it was translated from "saddharmapuNDariika-sutra"in Sanskrit by Kumarajiva (Sanskrit Kum{a-}raj{i-}va, abbreviated as Raju or Ju).

tit.e: Nichiren and Tendai sects of Buddhism

sen.j: 題目宗（日蓮宗、法華宗）の宗祖日蓮が正行（しょうぎょう）として据えたが、日蓮以前の天台大師（智顗）を祖とする天台宗・天台寺門宗などでも教義の中心ではないもののこの五字七字の題目は修行僧が唱えていたとされる。
sen.e: Nichiren, the founder of the chanting sects (Nichiren sect and Hokke sect) established this as correct practice were made to recite the chant but, prior to Nichiren, the 5 and seven character chant was not a central teaching of master Tendai (aka Chigi/Zhiyi) who founded the Tendai (Taiyi) and Tendai Jimon sects etc.

Nichiren, the founder of the chanting sects (Nichiren sect and Hokke sect) established this as a correct practice to recite the chant but, prior to Nichiren, the 5 and seven character chant was not a central teaching of master Tendai (aka Chigi/Zhiyi) who founded the Tendai (Taiyi) and Tendai Jimon sects.

Nichiren, the founder of the Daimoku sect (Nichiren sect, Hokke sect), defined Namu-myoho-renge-kyo as Shogyo (a correct practice); although, prior to Nichiren, it was not a center of the creed in Tendai and Tendai Jimon sects, which Tendai Taishi (Chigi or Zhiyi) founded, it was chanted by the ascetic priests of those sects.

sen.e: Nichiren who thought this practice emerged in final Dharma, also thought that primarily novice priests should not chant Nam-myoho-renge-kyo and this was not good practice following dissemination to Sado Island (Sado Province).
